snippet: In a 7-to-2 ruling Monday, the Supreme Court said an Arizona law requiring prospective voters to give proof of their citizenship was displaced by legislation at the federal level.
abstract: Supreme Court rules in 7-to-2 decision that Arizona may not require documentary proof of citizenship from people seeking to vote in federal elections there; ruling is second in two terms to reject Arizona laws that state’s officials have justified as responses to illegal immigration; in both cases, high court insisted that federal government has dominant role when it comes to national issues like controlling borders and how federal elections are conducted.

byline.contributor: Rebekah Zemansky contributed reporting from Tucson.

lead_paragraph: In a 7-to-2 ruling Monday, the Supreme Court said an Arizona law requiring prospective voters to give proof of their citizenship was displaced by legislation at the federal level.

headline.main: Justices Block Law Requiring Voters to Prove Citizenship
headline.print_headline: State Can’t Ask Voters for Proof Of Citizenship
